summary:
As the owner/operator of Reintegrate Counseling, LLC, I'm honored to work with individuals who want to lean into learning how to be proactive about behavior changes that will help them reach personal and professional goals.

Certificate Vocational Evaluator Forensic/Auburn University 2023

Certified Rehabilitation Counselor
ADC (S.C.)
Licensed Professional Counselor (S.C.)
Licensed Addiction Counselor (S.C.)
Case Manager 
Expertise: Traumatic Brain Injury, Transition to Work, Life After Trauma
Disability/Accessibility Services
fullName: Dede Norungolo, CRC, LPC, LAC, ADC
headline: Outpatient Therapist

message.text: https://lnkd.in/ewBv2tbX

Hard to believe it’s been a month since we headed to DC and asked for the reauthorization of the TBI Act! Here is an amazing video sharing about the brain injury journey. I’m honored to have been included.

Last month, I went to Washington D.C. to volunteer for the Brain Injury Association of America's (BIAA) Brain Injury Awareness Day, a rally on Capitol Hill. Me attending this event wasn't part of my work with them, but I didn't care. I wanted to go and experience it for myself (and see a bit of the work our team did for the event out in the wild!).

What I wasn't expecting is to meet so many incredible people connected with BIAA—some of them I'd met over Zoom calls as part of the focus group for the "My Brain Injury Journey" campaign—and get to give them hugs, hear their stories, and connect over the importance of a nonprofit like BIAA.

As part of that day's activities, rally participants were asked to talk about their brain injury journeys—how they'd explain them, what they didn't expect after their brain injury occurred, and what matters to them now. BIAA's Marketing & Communications Manager Lauren M. filmed these stories, and our team put them together in this video.

A huge thanks to Courtney Monday on our team for taking the "My Brain Injury Journey" logo a step further by illustrating it and bringing it to life. 

It's hearing these stories—and recognizing that every brain injury survivor is on a different path—that makes work like this really fulfilling.

#NonprofitDesign #MyBrainInjuryJourney #EventDesign #VisualBranding
Take a look at the Anderson, SC, role! Great opportunity.

Discover your next career move with Magellan Health! Explore our interactive job map to find openings in your area. #nowhiring #jobsearch #Jobseekers
https://lnkd.in/eX9W92DV

As a brain injury survivor, I had the opportunity to explore a variety of occupational pathways after discovering I could not maintain my position as a nonprofit manager after four months or more following my injury. With each work experience, I relied on my transferable skills to continue to navigate the work world. By 2006, I knew I wanted to help others with disabilities to discover their passions for work, academia, or community. Becoming a certified rehabilitation counselor is an honor and privilege.

Happy National Rehabilitation Counselors Appreciation Day 🥳

From all of us at CRCC, we're so grateful to support you and the crucial services you provide individuals with disabilities.

To celebrate, take 22% off select courses at CRCC eUNIVERSITY from March 22nd through March 24th: https://ow.ly/RFPs50QXYSy

Dede Norungolo and Anne Sexton took part in the virtual Walk, Run, Roll for Brain Injury 2024 on Sunday, March 17 on the Doodle Trail in Easley.

Dede is also one of our sponsors, with Reintegrate, a counseling service she started that serves individuals both in-person and remotely based in the Upstate of SC.  

In her own words, Dede says: 
“As a survivor and member of the BIASC Board of Directors, I was so happy to also serve as a sponsor for the event”.

Join us and make share to tag us  in your photos and use the hashtags #BrainInjuryAwarenessMonth #WalkRunRollForBrainInjuryAwareness 

Image Description: photo of Dede and Anne, two white women with short pixie cut hair styles. They are posing for a photo outside wearing the light blue 2024 Walk, Run, Roll t-shirt. A subset photo shows the logos on the back of the shirt with an arrow drawn to Reintegrate’s logo.

March is Brain Injury Awareness Month
 
BIA SC representatives among nearly 250 from 38 states calling for reauthorization of the Traumatic Brain Injury Act
 
Brain Injury Association of South Carolina (BIASC) representatives were among the nearly 250 individuals from 38 states advocating last week on Capitol Hill for the reauthorization of the Traumatic Brain Injury Act during Brain Injury Awareness Day on March 6, 2024.
Executive Director Joyce Davis, Board Member and TBI survivor Dede Norungolo, Brain Injury Advocate Eric Robinson, and DDSN TBI Grants Coordinator Qwendolyn Grant took part in advocacy training last week to ask Rep. William Timmons (R), Rep. Joe Wilson (R), Sen. Tim Scott (R), Sen. Lindsey Graham (R), and Rep. James Clyburn (D) for their continued support of the TBI Act.
Davis, of Columbia, Norungolo, of Greenville, Robinson, of Columbia, and Grant, of Blythewood, were on hand to encourage the South Carolina legislators to reauthorize and fully fund the act, support TBI model systems funding, and join the Congressional Brain Injury Task Force. Both Wilson and Clyburn are active members of the task force.
“Each of us has a unique brain injury journey, which we were able to share with our lawmakers,” said Norungolo, a Greenville, SC, native who experienced a TBI nearly 25 years ago. “No two brain injuries are alike. By coming together with others from across the United States we can communicate how important it is to have a more cohesive and proactive approach to treating individuals who experience concussion, TBI, stroke, and other brain injuries so that every incident is treated with the same level of care to promote the best possible outcome.”
The TBI Act provides much-needed funding to improve rehabilitation and community support for people with brain injury; it is set to expire in 2024. The Brain Injury Association of America worked with its partners and key stakeholders to craft improvements to the TBI Act, including expanding program eligibility and recognizing brain injury as a chronic condition, like diabetes and heart disease.
“The reauthorization of the TBI Act in 2024 is a pivotal opportunity to strengthen our nation’s response to the significant prevalence and complex challenges associated with brain injury,” said Rick Willis, president and CEO of the Brain Injury Association of America. “We’re making the case that long-term support for people with brain injury should be improved through the reauthorization of the Traumatic Brain Injury Act. We urge Congress to consider these proposed improvements, informed by consensus within the brain injury community, to ensure that every individual affected by a brain injury receives the care and support they need to live functional and independent lives.” 
For more information, please visit https://www.biaofsc.com/ or call 803-731-9823 for Executive Director, Joyce Davis.
Super grateful for the journey!

So many firsts this last week:

✔️ First rally on Capitol Hill
✔️ First time getting to meet the team from Brain Injury Association of America in person
✔️ First time getting to experience a client event where our branding was front and center

So proud of the BIAA team for executing a flawless Brain Injury Awareness Day. I was able to meet and talk with many brain injury survivors, hear their stories, and understand even more about why an organization like BIAA is so needed.

Our agency has worked with nonprofit organizations since the beginning. We love working with mission-driven clients, but sometimes when you're behind a computer or in front of a Zoom screen, it's easy to forget how much impact these organizations have for the people they serve.

Being in-person for this important event was a great reminder of why we do what we do. A huge thanks to the BIAA team for having me!

Dede Norungolo, CRC, LPC, LAC, ADC, Wendy Waldman, Brain Injury Association of Virginia, THE BRAIN INJURY ASSOCIATION OF INDIANA INC, Brain Injury Association of South Carolina

#BrainInjuryAssociationofAmerica #BrainInjuryAdvocacy #BrainInjuryAwarenessDay #BIAA

One of my favorite things is learning about new “tricks” or ways to live a more peaceful life whether through technology or accommodations. Lynda was truly one of the nicest people at the Brain Injury Awareness Day event (oh and her husband was the second nicest). We connected early in the mixing and mingling phase of the activities … she and her husband came to DC from California. It was during dinner at the hotel restaurant that I was starting to shut down due to the increased noise level. Lynda and her husband were at the table next to Joyce and I. Lynda was just totally enjoying her dinner. I could barely wait for our meal to be delivered - a salad. That’s when Lynda shared her super power with me! Yep - and now you know! @bia_usa @biaofsc I’ll be placing an order today!

So happy to have learned about a new program for individuals with invisible disabilities. https://lnkd.in/eSXMTdh8 Joyce Davis and Dede Norungolo stopped in the DC airport to ask about the program and its link to services. Here they are with Dennis Hazel, customer service manager at Reagan National. @biaofsc @bia_usa https://www.flyreagan.com/

message.text: What a great experience … to offer some insight into one brain injury journey and then to travel with so many others on their personal journeys!!!

From a proclamation by President Joe Biden to a closing conversation with Bill Pascrell https://lnkd.in/eM_JaAbr who authored the original TBI Act, BIASC representatives met staff of Rep. Williams Timmons, Rep. Joe Wilson, Sen. Tim Scott, Sen. Lindsey Graham, and Rep. James Clyburn March 6 to ask that they help reauthorize and fully fund the TBI Act, support TBI Model Systems Funding, and - if not already a member - that they join the Congressional Brain Injury Task Force. @bia_usa @biaofsc

Qwendalyn Grant, Dede Norungolo, Joyce Davis and Eric Robinson coordinate talking points in preparation for the Brain Injury Awareness Day on Capitol Hill. The South Carolina crew meets Rep. Williams Timmons, Rep. Joe Wilson, Sen. Tim Scott, Sen. Lindsey Graham, and Rep. James Clyburn March 6 to ask that they help reauthorize and fully fund the TBI Act, support TBI Model Systems Funding, and - if not already a member - that they join the Congressional Brain Injury Task Force. @bia_usa @biaofsc

Getting excited about traveling to DC to help represent brain injury survivors and thrivers for the Brain Injury Association of SC https://www.biaofsc.com/ during Brain Injury Awareness Month.  We will be asking government officials to reauthorize the TBI Act. https://lnkd.in/eTQiUWvw @biaofsc @bia_usa #BIASC

$25 for 25? Maybe that can be your contribution … it represents a dollar for each year (almost) since I experienced a moderate TBI. 

March is Brain Injury Awareness Month. The Brain Injury Association of South Carolina is offering a virtual 5K!!! Join me in supporting this amazing organization.
Sign up to run:
https://lnkd.in/eyeAkvQ6 (copy and paste link)
OR - just kick in some money to help my fundraising efforts:
https://lnkd.in/eDnv5RnM
Consider $25 for the 25 years (6/10/2024) that will mark the anniversary of the start of my brain injury journey. THANK YOU IN ADVANCE!!
